#Text=17.
#Text=The Coast of Oregon
#Text=When he had somewhat recovered , Rob sat up and looked around him .
#Text=The elder sailor was kneeling in earnest prayer , offering grateful thanks for his escape from suffering and death .
#Text=The younger one lay upon the ground sobbing and still violently agitated by recollections of the frightful experiences he had undergone .
#Text=Although he did not show his feelings as plainly as the men , the boy was none the less gratified at having been instrumental in saving the lives of two fellow-beings .
#Text=The darkness was by this time rapidly enveloping them , so Rob asked his companions to gather some brushwood and light a fire , which they quickly did .
#Text=The evening was cool for the time of year , and the heat from the fire was cheering and grateful ; so they all lay near the glowing embers and fell fast asleep .
#Text=The sound of voices aroused Rob next morning , and on opening his eyes and gazing around he saw several rudely dressed men approaching .
#Text=The two shipwrecked sailors were still sound asleep .
#Text=Rob stood up and waited for the strangers to draw near .
#Text=They seemed to be fishermen , and were much surprised at finding three people asleep upon the bluff .
#Text=" Whar ' n thunder ' d ye come from ? " asked the foremost fisherman , in a surprised voice .
#Text=" From the sea , " replied the boy .
#Text=" My friends here are shipwrecked sailors from the ' Cynthia Jane . ' "
#Text=" But how 'd ye make out to climb the bluff ? " inquired a second fisherman ;
#Text=" no one ever did it afore , as we knows on . "
#Text=" Oh , that is a long story , " replied the boy , evasively .
#Text=The two sailors had awakened and now saluted the new-comers .
#Text=Soon they were exchanging a running fire of questions and answers .
#Text=" Where are we ? " Rob heard the little sailor ask .
#Text=" Coast of Oregon , " was the reply .
#Text=" We 're about seven miles from Port Orford by land an ' about ten miles by sea . "

column1: #Text=" Do you live at Port Orford ? " inquired the sailor .
#Text=" That 's what we do , friend ; an ' if your party wants to join us we 'll do our best to make you comf'table , bein ' as you 're shipwrecked an ' need help . "
#Text=Just then a loud laugh came from another group , where the elder sailor had been trying to explain Rob 's method of flying through the air .
#Text=" Laugh all you want to , " said the sailor , sullenly ; " it 's true -- ev'ry word of it ! "
#Text=" Mebbe you think it , friend , " answered a big , good-natured fisherman ; " but it 's well known that shipwrecked folks go crazy sometimes , an ' imagine strange things .

#Text= I see you have found friends , " he said to them , " so I will leave you and continue my journey , as I 'm in something of a hurry . "

column1: #Text=Both sailors began to thank him profusely for their rescue , but he cut them short .
#Text=" That 's all right .

#Text=Of course I could n't leave you on that island to starve to death , and I 'm glad I was able to bring you away with me .

_	_	_	_

#Text= But you threatened to drop me into the sea , " remarked the little sailor , in a grieved voice .

column1: #Text=" So I did , " said Rob , laughing ; " but I would n't have done it for the world -- not even to have saved my own life .

#Text=He turned the indicator and mounted skyward , to the unbounded amazement of the fishermen , who stared after him with round eyes and wide open mouths .

#Text= This sight will prove to them that the sailors are not crazy , " he thought , as he turned to the south and sped away from the bluff .

column1: #Text=" I suppose those simple fishermen will never forget this wonderful occurrence , and they 'll probably make reg'lar heroes of the two men who have crossed the Pacific through the air . "
#Text=He followed the coast line , keeping but a short distance above the earth , and after an hour 's swift flight reached the city of San Francisco .
#Text=His shoulders were sore and stiff from the heavy strain upon them of the previous day , and he wished more than once that he had some of his mother 's household liniment to rub them with .
#Text=Yet so great was his delight at reaching once more his native land that all discomforts were speedily forgotten .

#Text=Much as he would have enjoyed a day in the great metropolis of the Pacific slope , Rob dared not delay longer than to take a general view of the place , to note its handsome edifices and to wonder at the throng of Chinese inhabiting one section of the town .

#Text=These things were much more plainly and quickly viewed by Rob from above than by threading a way through the streets on foot ; for he looked down upon the city as a bird does , and covered miles with a single glance .

#Text=Having satisfied his curiosity without attempting to alight , he turned to the southeast and followed the peninsula as far as Palo Alto , where he viewed the magnificent buildings of the university .

#Text=Changing his course to the east , he soon reached Mount Hamilton , and , being attracted by the great tower of the Lick Observatory , he hovered over it until he found he had attracted the excited gaze of the inhabitants , who doubtless observed him very plainly through the big telescope .

#Text=But so unreal and seemingly impossible was the sight witnessed by the learned astronomers that they have never ventured to make the incident public , although long after the boy had darted away into the east they argued together concerning the marvelous and incomprehensible vision .
#Text=Afterward they secretly engrossed the circumstance upon their records , but resolved never to mention it in public , lest their wisdom and veracity should be assailed by the skeptical .
